snippet: At the end of a nerve-racking day, Syrians were shocked by the president’s speech. Also relieved, bewildered, confused, triumphant and angry.
abstract: Syrian civilians express wide range of emotions, including shock, anger, confusion and relief, in response to Pres Obama's announcement that he will seek congressional approval before authorizing military strike against government forces.

byline.original: By ANNE BARNARD and HALA DROUBI
byline.contributor: Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, and Hala Droubi from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut; employees of The New York Times from Beirut and Damascus, Syria; and Karam Shomali from Antakya, Turkey.

lead_paragraph: At the end of a nerve-racking day, Syrians were shocked by the president’s speech. Also relieved, bewildered, confused, triumphant and angry.

headline.main: Obama’s Decision to Seek Approval First Lengthens Suspense of Attack
headline.print_headline: Obama’s Decision Bewilders Syrian Civilians and Draws Out Their Suspense
